The accidental release prevention and emergency response policy at the ERDC-CRREL facility.



It is the policy of Engineer Research and Development Center - Cold Regions Research and Engineering Laboratory (ERDC - CRREL) that we will maintain the capability, equipment and training to respond to and mitigate an accidental release of Anhydrous Ammonia.  This will be done in coordination with on-site and local emergency responders and is incorporated into the Local Emergency Planning Committee's (LEPC) Emergency Response Plan.  Furthermore, ERDC leadership has committed to supporting CRREL's membership on the Hanover/Lebanon LEPC by providing the financial resources, time and training to obtain and maintain a response capability.



Our facility and the regulated substances handled.



The Laboratory is located approximately two miles north of the town's center of Hanover, NH.  CRREL solves interdisciplinary and strategically important problems of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, U.S. Army, Department of Defense and the Nation by advancing and applying science and engineering to complex environments, materials, and processes in all seasons and climates, with unique core competencies related to the Earth's cold regions. The 30 acre site is bordered on the north by undeveloped land (previously a housing complex, but now demolished) to the  south by small housing areas, to the west by a narrow buffer of undeveloped land and the Connecticut River and on the east by a state highway and public school facility.  Within a half mile radius, there are additional housing complexes, office buildings, the Hanover Fire, Police and Emergency Medical Response complex, a nursing home, a senior living community, and a few small businesses.



CRREL's refrigeration system in the Ice Engineering Facility (IEF) uses anhydrous ammonia as the primary refrigerant.  Ammonia is an EPCRA Extremely Hazardous Substance with a Threshold Planning Quantity of 10,000 lbs.  The IEF system has a capac

ity in excess of the TPQ (20,000 lbs.) and as such is subject to EPCRA tier II reporting as well as the Risk Management Planning requirements.  No other EHS's above the TPQ exist at CRREL. 



The worst case release scenario and the alternative release scenario.



The worst case and alternate release scenarios were reviewed and analyzed during the Hazard Assessment conducted by Industrial Consultants on behalf of CRREL during April 2015. 



? The worst case release scenario was determined by the release of 5,700 lbs. of ammonia from the largest single vessel, High Pressure Receiver (HPR), over a 10 minute period. The capacity of this vessel is limited to 80% of its volume by engineering and administrative (SOP's) controls. Since the maximum ammonia inventory of 20,000 lbs cannot be stored within the HPR, a release of the capacity of the HPR will be the facility's worst case. The machine room where the HPR is located is considered a passive mitigation system. The distance to toxic endpoint was calculated to be 0.7 miles using the RMP*Comp program. 

? Various alternative release scenarios were analyzed but only one had the potential for creating an off-site endpoint. This scenario involves the over pressurization and venting through relief valves. The maximum release time to the outside air was determined to be 1 hour. The release time was limited to 1 hour because there are ammonia detectors located within the relief line, onsite ammonia plant operators who regularly perform monitoring rounds, and an emergency response team is available if needed. During the 1 hour period, the pressure relief valve will only be open intermittently. It is estimated that the fraction of time the valve is open will be 25%. The distance to toxic endpoint was calculated to be 0.1 miles using the RMP*Comp program.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention systems.



CRREL incorporated the elements of EPA's Risk Management Program into the act

ive OSHA's Process Safety Management program in 2015.  This includes the processes and procedures for Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training Programs, Contractors Safety, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, and Emergency Response.



Regular PSM/RMP meetings have been instituted with a committee composed of management, users, and employees involved in the process. The committee is in the process of updating all of the SOP's for the ammonia plant and its operation. A new machine room ventilation system is being installed during the summer/fall of 2015. To further enhance CRREL's ability to prevent accidental releases, we have increased the capacity of our ammonia alarm system, upgraded the automated operating system (SCADA), maintained our on-site emergency response team and eliminated our legacy emergency dump station.



The five year accident history



CRREL has not had a reportable release in the last five years.  



The Emergency Response Plan



CRREL has been a member of the EPCRA Hanover/Lebanon Local Emergency Planning Committee since its inception. Early in the process, it was recognized that there were no local resources available to respond to a major ammonia release from CRREL, other than for isolation and evacuation.  At the time, CRREL made a commitment to develop an in-house response team. All necessary equipment and HAZWOPER training was obtained.  A key element of the response program was that the Hanover Fire Department (HFD) would retain incident command for any release.  HFD is about 0.25 miles from CRREL, so a close working relationship has been developed in such areas as compatibility of radios and air tanks, providing and calibration of ammonia detectors, and frequent familiarization with CRREL personnel and facilities. Annual refresher training is conducted and alert systems have

been upgraded as previously described. Tabletop and simulated full-scale release scenarios are practiced each year with HFD participation.



Planned changes to improve safety



OSHA Process Safety Management and EPA Risk Management Program activities remain ongoing at CRREL.  During the fall/winter of 2015 a new mechanical room ventilation system will be installed to vent potential ammonia releases above the roof line. The legacy emergency dump station will be eliminated.
